metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dharampur Leather Company Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent, Dharampur Leather Company Ltd., Bombay (assessee company), was incorporated on June 15, 1943, as a private limited company, and later on November 24, 1949, it became a public limited company.
On August 1, 1949, the Dharampur State merged with the Province of Bombay.

Before its incorporation, the promoters of the assessee company had negotiated with the Ruler of Dharampur and secured from the Ruler total exemption from the State Income Tax of profits of the company for a period of seven years from the commencement of its working.
The factory commenced working from June 15, 1949.

After the merger the assessee company applied to the Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay, by its letter dated June 22, 1951, for relief under para 15 of the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949.

The Commissioner of Income Tax communicated the decision of the Government in his letter dated March 8, 1952, to exempt the company from income tax and super tax for a period of five years with effect from April 1, 1950. It was stated that the shareholders of the company would be liable to pay tax on the amount of dividend received by them.
Concerned with the assessment year 1955-56, accounting year being April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955.

The assessee contended before the Income Tax Officer in the course of the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1955-56 that this being the first assessment year after it commenced working as a factory, no depreciation had in fact been actually allowed to the assessee in any earlier assessment year, and, therefore, the depreciation should be computed on the original cost of the various items of plant and machinery and other assets of the company.

The Income Tax Officer rejected this contention and held that depreciation must be computed on the written-down values of machinery computed as if the income of the assessee had been worked out properly in the years when the company was exempted and the depreciation being allowed at the usual rates.
The assessee failed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal.
The Appellate Tribunal held that the words 'actually allowed' in s. 10(5)(b) of the Act were wide enough to cover the case of the assessee.

The High Court held that if in the prior years no depreciation had been actually allowed then the actual cost incurred by the assessee for acquiring the machinery would be the written down value of the machinery.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 7, 9, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in I.T. Reference No. 6 of 1960.

legal_issues.text: Whether depreciation is allowable on the original cost of the various components of the Plant and Machinery and other assets of the company as acquired and used prior to 1-7-1953.

Whether on a proper interpretation of S. 10(5)(b) of the Act, the depreciation must be deemed to have been allowed to the assessee in the years in which the income of the assessee company was exempted.

Whether the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, as amended by the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties (Amendment) Order, 1962, applies to the facts of the case.

petitioner_arguments.text: On a proper interpretation of S. 10(5)(b) of the Act, the depreciation must be deemed to have been allowed to the assessee in the years in which the income of the assessee company was exempted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 10(5)(b) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

petitioner_arguments.text: The Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, as amended by the 1962 Order, applies; the exemption was originally given by the Ruler under an agreement and the concession by the Commissioner was a continuance of the agreement, deemed granted under an agreement with the Ruler.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949 as amended by Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties (Amendment) Order, 1962

court_reasoning.text: Following judgment in Commissioner of Income Tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Messrs Straw Products Limited Bhopal, the words 'actually allowed' in para 2 of the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, do not include any notional allowance. Therefore, interpret 'actually allowed' in s. 10(5)(b) of the Act in the same manner. No force in appellant's first contention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'actually allowed' mean actually allowed, not deemed or notional.

court_reasoning.text: The Explanation inserted by 1962 Order has no bearing; exemption granted by Central Government under para 15 of Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949, issued under s.60A of the Act, so granted under the Act and not under any agreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exemption under statutory order, not agreement with Ruler.

holdings.text: Depreciation allowable on original cost since no depreciation actually allowed in prior exempted years; 'actually allowed' does not include notional allowance.
1962 Amendment Order does not apply as exemption granted under the Act, not under agreement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Messrs Straw Products Limited Bhopal
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds that 'actually allowed' does not include notional allowance; applied to interpret s.10(5)(b)

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs computation of depreciation on 'actually allowed' basis; exemption orders issued under S.60A

statutes_cited.name: Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides for application to Commissioner for continuance of exemptions granted by Rulers; under which assessee obtained exemption

statutes_cited.name: Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Interpretation of 'actually allowed'; referenced but distinguished

statutes_cited.name: Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties (Amendment) Order, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Sought to be applied by appellant but held inapplicable

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers under which Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949 issued

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave against the Bombay High Court, holding that depreciation is allowable on original cost as no depreciation was actually allowed in prior years, following Straw Products, and rejecting application of 1962 Amendment Order.
outcome.relief_granted: Depreciation on original cost upheld for assessee

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects notional depreciation during exemption periods

key_quotes.text: The exemption was granted under the Act and not under any agreement.
